section-block.rac_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Bb, Dd, Kk, Jj Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Practice saying the beginning letter sounds in bear, bike, dog, duck, jacket, jam, kite and
Sing to the tune of “Twinkle, Twinkle.” “Tickle, giggle, cuddle, grin. We are happy in our skin. It can heal. It can grow. It covers us from head to toe.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Happy in Our Skin. It was written by Fran Manushkin and illustrated by Lauren Tobia.
Pablo enjoys learning new things. He likes this informational text, which is all about our skin.
There is a question I want you think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the big book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you notice about the people in the park?
Look at the babies in their splendid skin. What are the babies doing?
The girl is tracing an outline of the boy to see how big he is. What happens to his skin as he grows?
Do the words skin and tin rhyme? Can you name another word that rhymes with skin?
Have you ever fallen down and hurt your skin? What happened?
Do you have lots and lots of skin? What parts of our bodies are covered with skin?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for children to Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud a short sentence telling something splendid about your skin.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where does our skin cover us?
Our skin covers our bodies from head to t____ (toe).
Our skin covers our bodies from head to toe.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s early experiences with language form the foundation for later language learning. This is true whether they hear and/or speak one language or many languages.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Understand Feelings and Actions
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a conversation about understanding the way children feel and the actions they use to show those feelings. Have children take turns completing this starter sentence: I feel happy so I ____ ; I feel sad so I _____ __ I feel angry so I _____ . Help children see by their examples that certain feelings lead to certain behaviors.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and see how the people in the book show their happy feelings as we revisit the book Happy in Our Skin, written by Fran Manushkin.
Clifford is very kind and always thinks about how people feel and behave.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages in the story where we see how people feel.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to select children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look at the book title and say the feeling, or emotion, we will read about today. Yes! Happy.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Look at the baby on these pages. How do you think the baby is feeling? (MB)
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How is the girl in this picture respecting the boy’s space? How do you know? (MB)
The people in this illustration are helping the girl who fell. Tell a partner how you would help someone who got hurt. (MB)
How does it feel when someone tickles your skin? Can you find the letter k in the word tickle?
Look at all of the one-of-a kind people! What are the children doing? How are they showing how happy they are?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit one of a kind Vocabulary Card.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children do to a happy dance with you. Sing and dance the “Hokey Pokey.” Children can move some of the body parts they read about in the book. Begin with these lyrics and continue.
You put your head in. You put your head out. You put your head in. And you shake it all about. You do the Hokey Pokey and you turn yourself around. That`s what it’s all about!
Transcribe children’s ideas as they talk about how happy they feel that their skin covers them from head to toe.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that helping children develop personal boundaries builds empathy. Helping children understand the rules of respecting other people’s personal space enables them to develop their own boundaries. (Argyle, 2013.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about how each of us is one of a kind. Use the book’s illustrations to show that people have one-of-a-kind characteristics.
Help children see likenesses and differences. Play “I Spy.” Have children stand if they are wearing something that matches the color or pattern you spy.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Happy in Our Skin by Fran Manushkin and illustrated by Lauren Tobia.
The book Happy in Our Skin tells us about skin. It tells us that skin comes in many colors. Pablo loves learning all about our bodies, especially our terrific skin!
This is the question I want you think about as we read:
What is special about our skin?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We all begin as babies, small and happy in our skin! What is one way your skin makes YOU happy?
What are the children showing us that their skin can do? What do you think it means when they say “keeps the outside out and your insides in”?
What does your clever skin do as you keep growing?
Pretend that you are freezing cold. Can you shiver? Can you feel goose pimples?
How does your skin feel on a hot day?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What is special about our skin?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as they describe something terrific about themselves.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens to our skin when we grow?
Our skin grows when we gr____ (grow).
Our skin grows when we grow.
What do children like about their skin?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Reading and talking about what makes each person “one of a kind” helps children learn to make observations on their own. Children begin to understand that each of us has features, customs, and characteristics that make us special. Understanding this means children are becoming more aware of themselves and others.

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that our skin can feel things. Our skin lets us know if something is hot or cold, or soft or hard. Let them take turns feeling different objects.
Remind children that two words that rhyme end with the same sound, such as skin and pin. Ask children to name words that rhyme with skin, hug, and small.
Introduce two new words from the Big Chart of Big Ideas.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look at the Big Chart Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes. We are going to sing about parts of our bodies and how they move.
Pablo loves to sing with you.
Happy in Our Skin and Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes are about parts of our bodies. Let’s listen for connections between the two texts!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept questions: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Use the prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you put your hands on your head? Can you say “yes” and “no” using only your head (no words)?
Put your hands on your shoulders. Can you make your shoulders go up and down?
Point to the boy’s knees. Let’s read the word “knee.”
Let’s all get up and use our knees to jump. Keep in your own space and be careful not to bump anyone. (MB)
How many toes do you have? Can you wiggle them inside your shoes?
Touch your skin. How does it feel?

section.rac_body-text: Sing or play a recording of “Head, Shoulders, Knees, Toes.” Encourage children to name the parts in their home language. Invite children to dance by moving only the body parts you call out. Then have children dance carefully around each other using their whole bodies. Encourage children to calm themselves down after they play. (MB)
Offer a writing prompt about how you use parts of your body and guide children’s response.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Add a two-minute sensory experience to your morning a few times a week. Play different types of music, breathe in new smells, touch objects from nature, or view a cultural artifact or something from nature. Children’s sensory knowledge will add up over time.

section-block.rac_body-text: Review pages 20 and 21 with children. Point out that each one of them is special and “nobody is you.” Help children understand the idea that everyone is different and has different fingerprints. Then have children share what they think makes them special. Ask friends to clap after each child shares to show their appreciation.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Happy in Our Skin.
Remember, this book is about how each of us is one of a kind. It tells how babies grow in their clever skin. Pablo loves to read about our-one-of-a-kind bodies.
As we read the big book again, I want you to think about this guiding question:
How can we move in the skin we’re in?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the big book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You were a baby once! Show how you moved before you could walk.
Touch your nose if you feel terrific in your skin.
Our faces show how we feel. Make some faces to show you are happy in the skin you’re in. (MB)
Can you share something one of a kind about you?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit one of a kind Vocabulary Card
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you find someone moving their arms? Show how you move your arms.
Can you see someone dancing to music? Show how you dance.
What sound do you hear that begins the word dance?
The people on these pages are very busy and happy in the skin they’re in. Act out something that makes you feel happy in your skin! (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can we move in the skin we’re in?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Possible responses:
Invite children to speak, draw, or write about something special that makes them special.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can we dance to music in the skin we’re in?
How do you like to move in your skin?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children love to read about children from other places. Teaching children about what makes other cultures special (traditions, food, music), as well as identifying similarities among them, can help them develop cultural awareness.
